[[Irena Popović]] | cinematography = [[Axel Schneppat]] | editing = Andrija Zafranovic | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2015|3|19|df=yes}} | runtime = 92 minutes | country = Germany
Serbia | language = Serbian
Albanian | budget = }} '''''Enclave''''' ({{lang-sr|Енклава}} / '''''Enklava''''') is a 2015 German-Serbian co-produced [[drama film]] directed by [[Goran Radovanović]].{{cite web |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/sydneylevine/35-films-that-could-become-foreign-language-oscar-submissions-20150826 |title=35 Films That Could Become Foreign Language Oscar Submissions |accessdate=3 September 2015 |work=Indie Wire}} It was one of six films shortlisted by Serbia to be their submission for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[88th Academy Awards]] but it was not nominated.{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/kultura/vesti.php?nav_category=268&yyyy=2015&mm=08&dd=14&nav_id=1027025 |title=Filmovi u konkurenciji za domaćeg kandidata za Oskara |work=B92|date=14 August 2015 |accessdate=14 August 2015}} On 3 September 2015 it was selected to represent Serbia for the Foreign Language Oscar.{{cite web|url=http://www.vijesti.me/caffe/enklava-srpski-kandidat-za-oskara-849736 |title="Enklava" - srpski kandidat za Oskara |work=Vijesti |date=3 September 2015 |accessdate=3 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oscars-serbia-selects-enclave-foreign-820400 |title=Oscars: Serbia Selects 'Enclave' for Foreign-Language Category |last=Holdsworth |first=Nick |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=4 September 2015 |accessdate=4 September 2015}} The main theme of the film is life of [[Kosovo Serbs]] in small isolated [[Kosovo Serb enclaves|ethnic enclaves]].{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/film-on-kosovo-serbs-in-bid-for-oscar-09-04-2015 |title=Film on Plight of Kosovo Serbs Bids for Oscar |work=Balkan Insight |date=7 September 2015 |accessdate=7 September 2015}} ==Plot== The film follows a young Serbian boy named Nenad, who was living in a ghetto that was the product of a previous war. Rather than having a linear plot line, the film focuses on the different unfortunate events in Nenad's life, sometimes revisiting past events. Specifically, the events are: * Nenad is driven to school each day in an armoured car. This is due to the discrimination against him by everyone not living in his enclave. There is only one teacher at his school and he is also the only student. However, his teacher later leaves the war-torn place, and his school trips end. * Nenad witnesses his grandfather die. * Nenad gets mixed up with some bad friends. After swimming with them, his clothes fall into the river and are lost. As a result he is whipped by his father. * A man attempts to steal Nenad's father's cattle and Nenad's father attempts to shoot him. The police arrive and arrest Nenad's father and confiscate all of his illegally owned weapons, which were kept in a box under his bed. The police offer Nenad's father a chance at employment at the police station, but he turns it down. * Nenad's hostile friends trap him under a giant bell for refusing to play a game, and the leading boy (Baskim) pulls out a pistol and shoots the bell. This causes the bullet to ricochet and hit Baskim. * Baskim's family questions him about who shot him. Baskim responds, "A Serb." Baskim's family and their gang set the Serbian enclave on fire, trapping Nenad under the bell tower. The heat and smoke nearly suffocates Nenad. Baskim feels guilt for trapping Nenad and revisits the bell where Nenad is trapped. * Nenad's family decides they want a new life and end up moving to [[Belgrade]] after they free Nenad from under the bell. Nenad is not used to a school with many people and as a result he does not perform well socially. ==Cast== * [[Filip Subarić]] as Nenad * [[Denis Murić]] as Baskim * [[Nebojša Glogovac]] as Vojislav Arsic * [[Anica Dobra]] as Milica Arsic * [[Miodrag Krivokapić (actor)|Miodrag Krivokapić]] as Otac Draža * [[Goran Radaković]] as Cekic * [[Meto Jovanovski (actor)|Meto Jovanovski]] as Milutin Arsic * [[Qun Lajçi]] as Baskim's grandfather * [[Nenad Jezdić]] as bus driver ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 88th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Serbian submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|2886632|Enclave}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Enclave}} [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Serbian films]] [[Category:Serbian drama films]] [[Category:Serbian-language films]] [[Category:Serbian enclaves in Kosovo]] [[Category:Films about children]] [[Category:Films about harassment]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]]

revision.comment: corrected the intro where it said over a ton to typically up to a ton
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} A '''fly crew''' is a group of people who operate a [[fly system]] from its locking rail during a theatrical production. The responsibilities of a fly crew include bringing [[batten (theater)|battens]] in and out, keeping the fly system linesets in balance, and ensuring that the fly system's [[rope lock]]s are applied when the associated linesets are not moving. Each member of the crew is called a ''flyman''. Large venues will often have several flymen on their fly crews, as well as a [[fly captain]] to manage the crew and plan cues for the fly system.
During a show, predefined cues may require flymen to operate the fly system at high speeds and with great precision. The scenery used in shows typically weigh up to one ton per batten {{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} and may be flown in at speeds approaching 30 miles per hour {{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} and stopped at stage level without hitting the deck. Consequently, the skills of a flyman may take years to master, and flying is often considered an art form in its own right. ''Loaders'' are flymen who work high above the stage in the grid, adding or removing counterweights from the fly system arbors.
==Safety== The job is often dangerous and carries a high degree of risk due to the large amount of weight and great heights involved. A run-away line, for example, might injure the operator or others in the way of the moving equipment, and a counterweight dropped from the grid could kill or injure a person standing below. When the crew adds or removes counterweights they are often working at heights of six stories or more in the area above a stage known as a [[fly loft]], or grid. Consequently, [[safety harness]]es may be used to protect fly crew members or loaders. Harnesses are not perfect, however, and serious injury can still result should the falling person swing into nearby objects.
==History== Historically, off-duty [[sailor]]s were used as fly crews in theaters because they had comprehensive knowledge of [[knot]]s and [[rope]]s due to their experience with [[sail]]s. They communicated with one another using high-pitched whistles. Because of this, whistling was not allowed in theaters to prevent it from accidentally being interpreted as a flyrail command. It is still considered 'bad luck' to whistle in a theater.
==Context==
This article uses terms common in the USA. Different vocabulary may be used in other English-speaking countries.
{{Running crew}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fly Crew}} [[Category:Stage crew]] [[Category:Theatrical occupations]]
{{Stagecraft-stub}}

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:Permalink/772743896#Future of magic links|local RfC]] and [[:mw:Requests for comment/Future of magic links|MediaWiki RfC]]
revision.text:
In [[folkloristics]], '''folk belief''' or '''folk-belief''' is a broad genre of [[folklore]]. This category includes a wide variety of behaviors, expressions, and beliefs. Examples of concepts included in this genre are [[Magic (supernatural)|magic]], [[popular belief]], [[folk religion]], [[planting signs]], [[hoodoo (folk magic)|hoodoo]], [[conjuration]], [[Spell (paranormal)|charms]], [[root work]], [[taboos]], [[old wives' tale]]s, [[omens]], [[portents]], the [[supernatural]] and [[folk medicine]].<ref name="GREEN-89">Green (1997:89).</ref>
Folk belief and associated behaviors are strongly evidenced among all elements of society, regardless of education level or income. In turn, folk belief is found in an agricultural, suburban, and urban environments alike.<ref name="GREEN-97">Green (1997:97).</ref>
==Terminology== One of a variety of compounds extending from the coinage of the term ''[[folklore]]'' in 1846 (previously ''popular antiquities''), the term ''folk-belief'' is first evidenced in use by British folklorist [[Laurence Gomme]] in 1892.<ref name="OED-folk-belief">"folk, n." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 3 November 2016. See also "folklore, n." OED Online. Oxford University Press, September 2016. Web. 3 November 2016.</ref>
Common parlance employs the word ''[[superstition]]'' for what folklorists generally refer to as ''folk belief''.<ref name="GEORGES-JONES-1995-122">For example, see discussion in Georges & Jones (1995:122).</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== * Georges, Robert A. & Jones, Michael Owen. 1995. ''Folkloristics: An Introduction''. Indiana University Press. {{ISBN|0253329345}}. * Green, Thomas A. 1997. ''Folklore: An Encyclopedia of Beliefs, Customs, Tales, Music, and Art''. Vol. 1. [[ABC-CLIO]].
{{Folklore genres}}
[[Category:Folkloristics]] [[Category:Folklore by type|Belief]] [[Category:Belief]]

{{pp-move-indef}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Frankie Boyle | image = Frankie Boyle 2008.jpg | caption = Boyle in 2008 | birth_name = Francis Martin Patrick Boyle | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1972|08|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Pollokshaws]], [[Glasgow]], Scotland | medium = [[Stand up comedy|Stand-up]], [[television]], [[radio]] | active = 1995–present | genre = [[One-liner joke|One-liners]], [[black comedy]], [[blue comedy]], [[satire]], [[insult comedy]] | subject = [[Culture of Scotland|Scottish culture]], [[celebrities]], [[politics]], [[family]], [[current events]] | domesticpartner = Shereen Taylor | children = 2 | website = {{url|frankieboyle.com}} }} '''Francis Martin Patrick Boyle'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/for-a-long-time-having-to-do-a-stand-up-gig-would-ruin-my-day-1-910220|title=For a long time, having to do a stand-up gig would ruin my day|date=24 July 2007|publisher=Scotsman.com|accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref> (born 16 August 1972) is a [[Scottish people|Scottish]] comedian and writer, well known for his [[pessimism|pessimistic]] and often controversial sense of humour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uktv.co.uk/dave/homepage/sid/7854 |title=Frankie Boyle : Dave |publisher=Uktv.co.uk |date= |accessdate=16 December 2011}}</ref>
He was a permanent panellist on the comedy panel show ''[[Mock the Week]]'' from its beginning in June 2005 until his departure in September 2009<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/north_east/8287297.stm | work=BBC News | title=Boyle leaves Mock The Week panel | date=2 October 2009}}</ref> and since then has made guest appearances on several other [[panel show]]s, as well as writing for [[Jimmy Carr]]'s ''[[Distraction (game show)|Distraction]]'' and [[Sean Lock]]'s ''[[TV Heaven, Telly Hell]]''.
== Early life == Boyle was born and raised in [[Pollokshaws]], [[Glasgow]] to [[Irish Catholic]] parents from the [[Crolly]] area of [[County Donegal]] in the west of [[Ulster]]. He attended [[Holyrood Secondary School]] in Glasgow. After leaving school, he worked as a library assistant over the summer and attended [[Langside College]].<ref name=lifesofar>{{cite news|title=My Shit Life So Far|url=http://www.harpercollins.co.uk/9780007460762/my-shit-life-so-far|accessdate=22 May 2016|publisher=Harper Collins}}</ref> He then studied Urban Planning at [[Aston University]] for a year before leaving and beginning a BA in English Literature at the [[University of Sussex]].<ref>{{cite interview |last=Boyle |first=Frankie |interviewer=Roz Laws |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/telly%3A+Confessions+of+an+urban+planner%3B+frankie+boyle+the+big...-a0189030560 |title=Confessions of an urban planner |publisher=Sunday Mercury |date=16 November 2008 |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite interview |last=Boyle |first=Frankie |interviewer=Rosanna Greenstreet |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/aug/24/frankie-boyle-comedian |title=Q&A: Frankie Boyle |publisher=guardian.co.uk |date=24 August 2012 |accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref> He graduated from university aged 22 and his first job was working in a [[Psychiatric hospital|mental health hospital]]. He then went to a teacher training college in [[Edinburgh]] and had placements in schools, but by then he was already performing as a [[stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]].<ref name=lifesofar /> He gained his big break after performing at [[The Stand Comedy Club]] in Edinburgh, a venue that has also helped launch the careers of [[Stewart Lee]], [[Johnny Vegas]], [[Peter Kay]], [[Dara Ó Briain]] and [[Michael McIntyre]].<ref>{{Cite news|author=Claire Sawers |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/comedy/article6962610.ece |title=Where Frankie Boyle got his shot at fame |publisher=Times Online |date=20 December 2009 |accessdate=24 December 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
== Career ==
=== Television ===
==== ''Mock the Week'' (2005–2009) ==== {{Main|Mock the Week}} Boyle was a regular on the BBC panel show ''[[Mock the Week]]'' from its first episode on 5 June 2005 until 17 September 2009. A show in which the panel comment humorously on various news stories from the [[Media of the United Kingdom|British media]], ''Mock the Week'' is hosted by [[Dara Ó Briain]], who in an episode of ''Live at the Apollo'' referred to Boyle as "the dark heart of ''Mock the Week''."<ref name="boyletimesonline">{{Cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/comedy/article5037516.ece |title=Is Frankie Boyle the UK's most shocking comic? |publisher=Times Online |date=1 November 2008 |accessdate=28 May 2015 | location=London | first=Stephen | last=Dalton | deadurl=yes | archivedate=15 June 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110615134953/http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/comedy/article5037516.ece}}</ref> He is known for his [[black comedy|morbid sense of humour]], which plays on negative images of celebrities, politicians, and society (particularly his home country of Scotland). On 2 October 2009, Boyle announced via the ''Mock the Week''{{'}}s Facebook fan page that he was leaving the show to concentrate on other projects.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/north_east/8287297.stm |title=Boyle leaves Mock The Week panel, BBC, 2 October 2009 |publisher=BBC News |date=2 October 2009 |accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> Boyle has since criticised both the show's production team and the [[BBC Trust]]. He claims that the show did not cover enough major news stories, and was too restrictive on his risqué comedy act because the producers and the BBC Trust were afraid of "frightening the horses".<ref name="MSN">{{Cite news|title=Frankie Boyle slams Mock The Week |url=http://tv.uk.msn.com/news/articles.aspx?cp-documentid=150480748&GT1=61503 |work=uk.msn |date=27 October 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2009}}</ref> He is seen in archive footage of ''Mock the Week'' on the 2009 Christmas Special, which aired on 22 December 2009, as a series of "Best Bits and Festive Clips", in a compilation celebrating the show's 100th episode on 5 July 2012 as well as in archive footage on the 2012 Christmas Special, which aired on 27 December 2012.
==== ''Frankie Boyle's Tramadol Nights'' (2010) ==== {{Main|Frankie Boyle's Tramadol Nights}} In October 2009, Boyle piloted a sketch and stand-up show for [[Channel 4]], entitled ''Deal with This, Retards'' to be produced by RDF Scotland subsidiary the [[Comedy Unit]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Parker |first=Robin |url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/broadcasters/bbc/boyle-quits-mock-the-week/5006386.article |title=Broadcast Now, 2 October 2009 |publisher=Broadcastnow.co.uk |date=2 October 2009 |accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> Boyle mentioned on ''[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]'' that the original title of the show had been dropped, due to its offensive nature, and been renamed ''[[Frankie Boyle's Tramadol Nights|Tramadol Nights]]'' and aired from the end of November 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/news/a259760/frankie-boyle-dismisses-comedy-controversy.html|title=Frankie Boyle dismisses comedy controversy|author=Mayer Nissim|publisher=Digital Spy|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> An official page launched via Channel 4's official website, which confirmed that the show's full name is ''Frankie Boyle's Tramadol Nights'' and the series was made up of six episodes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/frankie-boyles-tramadol-nights |title=Frankie Boyle's Tramadol Nights |publisher=Channel 4 |date=29 December 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2011}}</ref> Boyle caused controversy on the show with his comments about [[Katie Price]] and [[Dwight Yorke]]'s disabled son Harvey.<ref>https://www.ofcom.org.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0028/46729/obb179.pdf</ref>
==== ''Frankie Boyle's Rehabilitation Programme'' pilot (2011) ====
On 21 August 2011, it was revealed that Channel 4 had given Boyle permission to record a pilot for a topical talk show in October of that year, which would be called ''Frankie Boyle's Rehabilitation Programme'' (despite the controversy surrounding ''Frankie Boyle's Tramadol Nights''). Channel 4 head of comedy Shane Allen told the press that "it's very much like ''[[Parkinson (TV series)|Parkinson]]'' or ''[[Wogan]]'', but with paedo jokes" and that the show would feature Frankie "in a studio, riffing off the audience a bit with some people challenging what he says".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2011/aug/21/frankie-boyle-pilot-channel-4 |title=Channel 4 line up return for Frankie Boyle |publisher=The Guardian |date=21 August 2011 |accessdate=17 June 2012 |location=London |first=Patrick |last=Foster}}</ref>
==== ''The Boyle Variety Performance'' (2012) ==== ''The Boyle Variety Performance'' was broadcast on 19 August 2012 and featured Boyle with guests [[Rob Delaney (comedian)|Rob Delaney]], [[Nick Helm]], [[Katherine Ryan]] and [[Tom Stade]]. A few days after the show was broadcast, Boyle attracted criticism after he posted jokes on Twitter about the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/aug/31/frankie-boyle-paralympics-twitter-jokes?newsfeed=true |title=Frankie Boyle Paralympics Twitter jokes prove last straw for Channel 4 |publisher=The Guardian |date=30 August 2012 |accessdate=1 September 2012 |location=London |first=Josh |last=Halliday}}</ref>
==== ''Gasping'' (2014) ==== In 2014, Frankie Boyle starred in the short comedy film ''Gasping'' for BBC Scotland, written by [[Greg Hemphill]]. The title refers to an expression in [[Scottish English]], communicative of an irresistible compulsion to do something, such as smoke a cigarette; or, as here, to drink alcohol. The short feature, an at-times-farcical but generally deadpan treatment of a man's attempted recovery from alcoholism.
==== ''Frankie Boyle's Autopsy Series'' (2014–2016) ==== ''Frankie Boyle's Referendum Autopsy'' was released on 28 September 2014, and ''Frankie Boyle's Election Autopsy'' was released on 17 May 2015, through [[BBC iPlayer]]. Featuring guests Katherine Ryan and [[Sara Pascoe]], Boyle dissected the [[Scottish independence referendum]], 2014 and [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|general election]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/may/20/frankie-boyle-bbc-election-autopsy-comedy-iplayer|title=Frankie Boyle’s Election Autopsy is too hot for TV – so much the better|last=Logan|first=Brian|date=20 May 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref> ''Frankie Boyle's American Autopsy'' dissected the buildup and fallout of the United States presidential election, tackling topics such as feminism, entertainment, propaganda, and guns. Special guests include Sara Pascoe, Katherine Ryan, [[Michelle Wolf]], Desiree Burch, and [[Richard Osman]].
==== ''Frankie Boyle's New World Order'' (2017–present) ==== A show similar to his BBC iPlayer exclusive "autopsy" shows, Boyle returned to TV on [[BBC Two]], with his ''[[Frankie Boyle's New World Order]]'', which follows a very similar structure to the aforementioned programmes, where Frankie makes two statements, and discusses them with his guests. The difference is that the studio audience do not vote on if they agree with that statement. The show premiered on 8 June 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2017-05-25/bbc2-to-broadcast-new-frankie-boyle-satirical-show-right-after-general-election-polls-close|title=Frankie Boyle' new BBC political comedy to air right after UK Election 2017 polls close|last=Dowell|first=Ben|date=25 May 2017|work=[[Radio Times]]|accessdate=22 June 2017}}</ref>
=== Radio ===
==== ''Blocked'' pilot (2014) ==== A sitcom set in a small regional theatre starring [[David Mitchell (comedian)|David Mitchell]] as a happy-go-lucky writer with writer's block written by Frankie Boyle and Steven Dick, broadcast on [[BBC Radio 4]] on 5 June 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/radio/blocked/ | title=Blocked |publisher=British Comedy Guide |accessdate=11 June 2014}}</ref>
=== Books === On 1 October 2009, Boyle's autobiography ''[[My Shit Life So Far]]'' was released,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intelligentconversation.co.uk/?p=21 |title=Frankie Boyle launches his autobiography |publisher=Intelligent Conversation |date=22 September 2009 |accessdate=7 December 2009}}</ref> published by [[HarperCollins]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=My Shit Life So Far |last=Boyle |first=Frankie |year=2009 |publisher=[[Harper Collins]] |isbn=978-0-00-732449-1 |page=291}}</ref> His second book ''Work! Consume! Die!'' was released in October 2011. Boyle's third book, ''Scotland's Jesus: The Only Officially Non-racist Comedian'', was released in the UK on 24 October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.harpercollins.co.uk/Titles/64283/scotlands-jesus-frankie-boyle-9780007426836 |title=Scotland's Jesus |publisher=Harper Collins |date= |accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref>
=== Live shows === In October 2007 Boyle embarked on a stand-up tour of Britain, playing over 100 dates and enjoying a sold-out run that was extended through until December 2008. Boyle said that he planned to quit stand-up before he turned 40, had written his final tour and plans to do more television work after this.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2009/07/02/9213/boyle%3A_im_quitting_stand-up |title=Boyle: I'm Quitting Stand up |publisher=Chortle.co.uk |date= |accessdate=26 July 2009}}</ref> Boyle performed the tour, entitled ''I Would Happily Punch Every One of You in the Face'' between March and December 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ticketmaster.co.uk/Frankie-Boyle-Live-tickets/artist/953249?CAMEFROM=CFC_UK_EV0542_WEBLINK |title=Frankie Boyle Live Tickets |publisher=Ticketmaster |date= |accessdate=7 December 2009}}</ref><!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:FrankieBoyleLiveDVD.jpg|thumb|upright|Cover of his live DVD]] -->
On 21 November 2011, at a "Meet the Comedians" session in the [[Apple Store]], [[Regent Street]] with [[Jimmy Carr]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/meet-comedians-jimmy-carr/id484003108 |title=iTunes – Podcasts – Meet the Comedians: Jimmy Carr and Frankie Boyle by Events at the Apple Store |publisher=Itunes.apple.com |date=28 November 2011 |accessdate=16 December 2011}}</ref> Boyle announced he was doing another tour entitled ''The Last Days of Sodom'', despite intending ''I Would Happily Punch Every One of You in the Face'' to be his final one. He mentioned the tour will not be as long as its predecessor. His website has stated it will run from July to December 2012 with more dates to be added.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frankieboyle.com/tourdates.html |title=Frankie Boyle |publisher=Frankie Boyle |date= |accessdate=16 December 2011}}</ref> Tickets went on sale in December 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ticketmaster.co.uk/Frankie-Boyle-Live-tickets/artist/33779 |title=Frankie Boyle Live Tickets 2012|publisher=Ticketmaster |date= |accessdate=9 December 2011}}</ref>
=== DVD releases === On 10 November 2008, Boyle's first DVD was released,<ref name="boyletimesonline" /> featuring a sell-out stand-up performance given at London's [[Hackney Empire]] and some additional material, including a documentary about the tour, entitled ''Fuck You Scotland'', and some sketches from the [[BBC Three]] comedy ''[[Rush Hour (UK TV series)|Rush Hour]]''.<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Frankie Boyle Live DVD |titlelink= |year= |others=Brian Klein |publisher=[[Channel 4]] |location= |id= |language= }}</ref> The DVD was described by WhatDVD.net as "certainly not one to watch with your grandparents – not unless they are pretty open-minded!"<ref>{{cite web|author=Lianne |url=http://www.whatdvd.net/frankie-boyle-live-dvd-review-122.html |title=Frankie Boyle Live DVD Review |publisher=WhatDVD.net |date=13 November 2008 |accessdate=7 December 2009}}</ref>
Boyle has also featured in three DVD compilations of material from ''[[Mock the Week]]''. The compilations, entitled ''Too Hot for TV'', include material deemed too offensive for broadcast on TV and uncut versions of several full episodes. Boyle's second live DVD, ''If I Could Reach Out Through Your TV and Strangle You I Would'', was released on 15 November 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.play.com/DVD/DVD/4-/12041662/Frankie-Boyle-Live-2-I-Would-Happily-Punch-Every-One-Of-You-In-The-Face/Product.html |title=''Play.com'' – Frankie Boyle Live 2 |publisher=Play.com |date= |accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
=== Podcast === On 16 July 2009, Boyle's first podcast was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendId=114749422&blogId=500565493 |title=Frankie's Podcast |publisher=MySpace |date=16 July 2009 |accessdate=30 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=6 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106081646/http://www.myspace.com/frankieboylelive/blog/500565493}}</ref> Entitled ''Mock the Week Musings'', the podcast is a recording of Boyle testing the material he has written for ''Mock the Week'' to a London audience. Boyle comments on his material throughout and often informs the audience that certain jokes are not going into the show due to their reaction (or lack thereof), and the podcast carries an explicit content warning. The recording includes some audience interaction, with Boyle offering to test some of his new "put-downs" on the crowd.<ref>{{cite podcast | url=https://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewPodcast?id=323684930 | title=Mock The Week Musings | website=[[iTunes]] | publisher=BBC | host=Frankie Boyle | date=16 July 2009 | accessdate =24 December 2009}}</ref>
Between 2013 and 2015, Boyle, along with Canadian comedian [[Glenn Wool]] hosted a number of editions of a podcast known as Freestyle, which involved Boyle and Wool speaking about topical and controversial news stories, including [[Madeleine McCann]], [[Bill Cosby]], and obscure takes on popular culture.<ref>{{cite podcast | title=Freestyle |url=http://frankieboyle.podbean.com/ |}}</ref>
=== Comic book === In September 2010, Boyle began publishing his comic strip ''Rex Royd'' in the launch issue of ''[[CLiNT]]'' magazine, co-written with comedian Jim Muir and with artwork by Michael Dowling.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=37302 |title=CLINT WEEK: COMEDIAN FRANKIE BOYLE ROCKS "REX ROYD" |publisher=CBR |date=2 March 2012 |accessdate=12 August 2013}}</ref> The story follows a [[Lex Luthor]]-style newspaper magnate with a super-villain alter-ego. Initially, the strip ran for first four issues of ''CLiNT''. The strip resumed again in November 2011, until the final issue in August 2013, when publisher [[Titan Magazines|Titan]] announced that ''CLiNT'' was ending.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=47315 |title=Comicbookresources.com |publisher=Comicbookresources.com |date=14 August 2013 |accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
=== Other appearances === Boyle appeared as himself in the video game ''[[Grand Theft Auto: The Lost and Damned]]'' (2009), in a stand-up routine at Liberty City's Split Sides Comedy Club. He appeared on Real Radio Wales's weekly comedy show ''Comedy Nighthorse'' on 19 October 2011. Boyle writes satire and opinion pieces for the British newspaper [[The Guardian]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/profile/frankie-boyle|title=Frankie Boyle|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
== Controversy == Boyle has regularly been involved in public controversies due to the acerbic nature of his humour.
=== Rebecca Adlington === Boyle managed to attract criticism in August 2008 when complaints were received about comments he made regarding British Olympic swimmer [[Rebecca Adlington]] on ''Mock the Week'', saying that she "looks like someone who's looking at themselves in the back of a [[spoon]]". The BBC ruled that the jokes were indeed "humiliating" and "risked offending the audience", while also calling Boyle "a brilliant member of the team".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8314495.stm |title='Mock' rapped over swimmer jibes |publisher=BBC |date=19 October 2009 |accessdate=14 December 2009}}</ref> Despite this, Adlington's agent said that simply admitting mistakes was not enough, saying: "By giving Frankie Boyle a rebuke they fail to discourage others from doing the same."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8337421.stm |title=Swimmer queries Mock show ruling |publisher=BBC |date=2 November 2009 |accessdate=14 December 2009}}</ref> Adlington later went on to comment on this issue.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8575567/Rebecca-Adlington-Im-over-the-Frankie-Boyle-spoon-jibe.html |title=Rebecca Adlington: I'm over the Frankie Boyle spoon jibe |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=20 October 2011 |location=London |first=Anita |last=Singh}}</ref>
=== The Queen === In October 2008, during [[The Russell Brand Show prank telephone calls row|''The Russell Brand Show'' prank telephone calls row]], Boyle found himself in the midst of a scandal when the BBC broadcast a ''Mock the Week'' repeat in which he made a joke about [[Elizabeth II|the Queen]]. Whilst pretending to be the Queen in the "Scenes We'd Like To See" segment of ''Mock The Week'', Boyle said "I am now so old, my pussy is haunted". This caused many to complain about the state that the BBC had come to, with [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP [[David Davies (Welsh politician)|David Davies]] calling the joke a "disgracefully foul comment".<ref>{{cite web|author=Rashid Razaq |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23580712-corporation-attacked-for-offensive-joke-about-the-queen.do |title=Corporation attacked for offensive joke about the Queen |publisher=ThisIsLondon.co.uk |date=31 October 2008 |accessdate=14 December 2009}}</ref> Boyle was eventually cleared of any misconduct by the BBC Trust, although they called the comment "sexist and ageist".<ref>{{Cite news|author=Tara Conlan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/oct/19/frankie-boyle-mock-the-week |title=Frankie Boyle's 'sexist' joke about Queen cleared by BBC Trust |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=19 October 2009 |accessdate=14 December 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
=== Down's syndrome === In a performance on his 2010 tour, Boyle interrupted a "long, seemingly semi-improvised skit" about [[Down syndrome]] by challenging a woman in the front row who seemed uncomfortable with the material.<ref name="guardian" /> The audience member explained that her five-year-old daughter had the condition and strongly criticised Boyle's portrayal of people with Down syndrome.<ref name="guardian">{{Cite news | last = Walker | first = Peter | title = Frankie Boyle meets his match in mother of a child with Down syndrome | newspaper = The Guardian | publisher = Guardian News and Media Limited | date = 8 April 2010 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/apr/08/frankie-boyle-downs-syndrome | accessdate =12 April 2010 | location=London | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8611275.stm |title=Frankie Boyle criticised for Down's syndrome joke |publisher=BBC |date=9 April 2010 |accessdate=10 April 2010}}</ref><ref name="mencap">{{cite web|url=http://www.mencap.org.uk/news.asp?id=14385&detail=2Frankie |title=Frankie Boyle in Down's syndrome row |publisher=[[Mencap]] |date=9 April 2010 |accessdate=10 April 2010}}</ref> [[Mencap]] spokesman Ismail Kaji said that the comments could be misconstrued and seen as "no different to bullying".<ref name="mencap" />
=== Palestine and Israel === In April 2010, the [[BBC Trust]]'s Editorial Standards Committee apologised for a joke made by Boyle on [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]] panel show ''[[Political Animal (radio show)|Political Animal]]'' in which he likened the situation in [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] to "a cake being punched to pieces by a very angry [[Jewish|Jew]]". Boyle also made another joke where he said that he had "been studying Israeli Army martial arts. I now know 16 ways to kick a Palestinian woman in the back".<ref name="palestinerow">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8650254.stm |title=BBC apologises for Frankie Boyle joke |publisher=BBC |date=28 April 2010 |accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref> In response, Boyle published a letter in which he criticised the Trust's "cowardly rebuke of my jokes about Palestine" and reprinted the jokes in question. He then criticised the BBC for not broadcasting a humanitarian appeal during the 2008–2009 [[Gaza War (2008–09)|Gaza War]], saying that it was "tragic for such a great institution but it is now cravenly afraid of giving offence and vulnerable to any kind of well drilled lobbying." Boyle then said that the situation in Palestine "seems to be, in essence, apartheid", concluding that he had reached this position after watching a documentary about life in Palestine that he said had driven him to tears.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Boyle | first = Frankie | author-link = | title = Frankie Boyle letter about BBC in full | newspaper = The Telegraph | date = 1 May 2010 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/7660232/Frankie-Boyle-letter-about-BBC-in-full.html | accessdate =1 May 2010 | location=London | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref>
In 2018, Boyle accused BBC television producers of "editing out" comments he made on ''New World Order'' about [[2018 Gaza border protests| Palestinian deaths on the Gaza border]] and his joke about "Israel being an Apartheid state”.<ref name="newworldediting">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/frankie-boyle-new-world-order-antisemitism-bbc-1.464439 |title=Frankie Boyle claims 'Apartheid' Israel jokes were cut from BBC show |publisher=The Jewish Chronichle|date=22 May 2018 |accessdate=28 May 2018}}</ref>
=== Harvey Price === In December 2010, both [[Katie Price]] (a.k.a. Jordan) and [[Peter Andre]] were said to have been left "absolutely disgusted and sickened" by a joke that was made on ''[[Frankie Boyle's Tramadol Nights]]'' about Price's heavily disabled son, Harvey. On the show, Boyle said: "Apparently Jordan and Peter Andre are fighting each other over custody of Harvey. Well eventually one of them will lose ... and have to keep him." Then he added: "I have a theory that Jordan married a cage fighter ([[Alex Reid (fighter)|Alex Reid]]) because she needed someone strong enough to stop Harvey from fucking her."<ref name="pricejoke">{{Cite news|author=Christian Tobin |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/news/a292233/price-andre-sickened-by-frankie-boyle-joke.html |title=Price, Andre "sickened" by Frankie Boyle joke |publisher=[[DigitalSpy]] |date=9 December 2010 |accessdate=3 January 2011}}</ref>
Andre's representative also responded to the comments made by Boyle and said "We're all disgusted by these comments. Peter is angry and very upset at Harvey being mocked in this way. Children, especially a disabled youngster, should be off-limits." Both confirmed that they had sought legal action and wrote a complaint to Channel 4 regarding Boyle's jokes with Price saying: "To bully this unbelievably brave child is despicable; to broadcast it is to show a complete and utter lack of judgement. I have asked my lawyers to write to Channel 4."<ref name="pricejoke" /> [[Ofcom]] confirmed that Price issued a complaint and accordingly launched an investigation into the programme.<ref name="tramadolinvestigated">{{Cite news|author=John Plunkett |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/dec/10/frankie-boyle-katie-price |title=Frankie Boyle's Katie Price joke sparks Ofcom investigation |publisher=The Guardian |date=10 December 2010 |accessdate=3 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref> In April 2011, Ofcom ruled Channel 4 had breached broadcasting rules by transmitting the material in question but did not require the network to broadcast an apology saying that it was an "erroneous decision on a matter of editorial judgment on the broadcaster's part". Price criticised the decision not to require a broadcast apology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23938327-ofcom-slams-frankie-boyle-jokes-about-katie-prices-disabled-son-harvey.do |title=Ofcom slams Frankie Boyle 'jokes' about Katie Price's disabled son Harvey |publisher=Thisislondon.co.uk |date=4 April 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
Boyle discussed the material onstage at a charity gig some months later, saying that the joke was intended to highlight how Price exploited her son, and that he felt the two aspects of Price's media profile, "her disabled son and her sexuality", did not belong together. He rejected comments that the joke may have led to playground bullying, saying that "I find it hard to believe there are kids at that school who would like to slag Harvey, but can't think of an angle."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2011/03/22/13005/frankie_boyle_stands_firm_over_harvey_gag |title=Chortle.co.uk |publisher=Chortle.co.uk |date=22 March 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref>
=== Allegations of racism and consequent libel action === In July 2011, the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' published an article strongly criticizing Boyle which alleged he had been forced to quit ''Mock the Week'' and described him as a "racist comedian". Boyle, in response, sued the ''Mirror'' for libel. In October 2012, a jury found in his favour, ordering the ''Mirror'' to pay him £54,650 in damages, all of which he donated to charity.<ref>{{cite news|last=Halliday|first=Josh|title=Frankie Boyle wins more than £50,000 libel damages from Daily Mirror|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/22/frankie-boyle-libel-damages-daily-mirror|accessdate=23 October 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=22 October 2012|location=London}}</ref>
=== ''Give It Up for Comic Relief'' === On 6 March 2013, Boyle caused controversy when he was invited to perform at [[Russell Brand]]'s [[BBC Three]] fundraiser ''Give It Up for Comic Relief'' at [[Wembley Arena]]. He made a series of jokes about Comic Relief itself, [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]], [[Oscar Pistorius]], [[Pope Benedict XVI]] and the [[Jimmy Savile sexual abuse scandal]].<ref name="Independent">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/i-wish-the-queen-had-died-offensive-frankie-boyle-jokes-cut-from-bbc-comic-relief-broadcast-8524030.html|title='I wish the Queen had died': Offensive Frankie Boyle jokes cut from BBC Comic Relief broadcast|work=[[The Independent]]|date=7 March 2013|accessdate=8 April 2013|location=London|first=Daisy|last=Wyatt}}</ref> This was deemed so distasteful that his entire six-minute performance was cut out of the broadcast version of the 3.5-hour show.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/03/07/frankie-boyle-russell-brand-give-it-up-for-comic-relief-_n_2826899.html | title=Frankie Boyle Axed From Russell Brand's 'Give It Up For Comic Relief' Show On BBC Three Over 'Disgusting' Jokes | work=[[The Huffington Post]] | date=7 March 2013 | accessdate=9 April 2015}}</ref>
== Personal life == Boyle lives in [[Glasgow]] with his girlfriend, Shereen Taylor,<ref name="boylebirmingham">{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-189030560.html |title=Confessions of an Urban Planner; Frankie Boyle The Big Interview |publisher=Sunday Mercury |date=16 November 2008 |accessdate=21 December 2009}}</ref> and has two children: a daughter (born 2004) and a son (born October 2007). He has admitted that his career had caused him to neglect his family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nowmagazine.co.uk/celebrity-news/tv-news/290432/frankie-boyle-i-ll-quit-comedy-in-two-years/1/ |title=Frankie Boyle: I'll quit comedy in two years |publisher=Nowmagazine.co.uk |date=27 December 2008 |accessdate=26 July 2009}}</ref> He is a recovering alcoholic, having started drinking at the age of fifteen and stopping at 26, and is also former drug user, who now maintains a life of [[sobriety]] (a [[teetotalism|teetotaller]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nowmagazine.co.uk/celebrity-news/281140/frankie-boyle-i-ve-done-cannabis-ecstasy-and-lsd/1/ |title=Frankie Boyle: I've done cannabis, ecstasy and LSD |publisher=Nowmagazine.co.uk |date=11 November 2008 |accessdate=26 July 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Wyllie|first=Alice|url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/comment/Profile-Frankie-Boyle-Frankie-mocks.5681959.jp|title=Profile: Frankie Boyle: Frankie mocks the weak|publisher=[[Scotland on Sunday]]|date=27 September 2009|accessdate=27 September 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120717041055/http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/comment/Profile-Frankie-Boyle-Frankie-mocks.5681959.jp|archivedate=17 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
He is a follower of [[Noam Chomsky]] and says that he has had a great influence on his political beliefs, claiming to be more [[left-wing politics|left-wing]] than Chomsky himself.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/dec/19/frankie-boyle-celebrity-memoirs | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Stuart | last=Jeffries | title=Frankie Boyle lays into celebrity memoirs as his own is a surprise hit | date=19 December 2009}}</ref> During one of his interviews, he has also claimed to be a follower of [[Advaita Vedanta]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qDQJ8gQHvME |title=frankie boyle the interview |publisher=YouTube |date=4 August 2013 |accessdate=8 April 2014}}</ref>
In July 2013, Boyle supported [[Shaker Aamer]], the last UK resident being held at [[Guantanamo Bay]], by going on a [[hunger strike]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23389757|title=Frankie Boyle hunger strike in support of Shaker Aamer|work=BBC News|date=20 July 2013|accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref>
Boyle is a supporter of the Glasgow-based [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] Football Club.
Boyle's comedy influences include [[Billy Connolly|Sir Billy Connolly]], [[Bill Hicks]] and [[Spike Milligan]]. The fellow Scottish shock comedian [[Jerry Sadowitz]] is often cited as an influence on Boyle, although Boyle himself has discounted this.{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}}
Boyle is a supporter of [[Scottish independence]]. When asked "How do you feel about independence?" Frankie replied with "Yes, I think we should be independent. What have we got to lose? A [[Conservative Party (UK)|Tory]] government? I'm looking forward to the vote just because it will be a novelty for Scottish people to fill in official forms while still in possession of their own belt and shoelaces. And imagine what Scotland's annual Independence Day celebrations will look like; the fucking D-Day Landings." Boyle revealed via his Twitter account that he votes for the [[Scottish Green Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/comedy/features/306416-what_offends_frankie_boyle|title=What Offends Frankie Boyle?|work=The Skinny|date=4 December 2013|accessdate=22 February 2014}}</ref>
Throughout 2017, Boyle supported [[Jack Thomas (swimmer)|Jack Thomas]], a British Paralympic swimmer who suffered a number of unfortunate career setbacks, via Twitter and through donations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/wales/41672180|title=Jack Thomas: Swimmer's funding boost from Frankie Boyle and Michael Sheen|date=2017-10-18|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2017-12-28|language=en-GB}}</ref>
During an interview on [[The Jonathan Ross Show]] in 2012, Boyle revealed that he has a fear of flying, and travels to shows in England by train.

[[Comedy]] | creator = Carl Jones
[[Nick Weidenfeld]] | writer = Carl Jones
Nick Weidenfeld | director = [[Chris Prynoski]] | creative_director = Jacob Escobedo | voices = (See [[#Voice cast|Voice cast]]) | theme_music_composer = [[Tha Bizness]] | opentheme = "Freaknik Is Back", {{small|performed by [[T-Pain]]}} | endtheme = "Ghetto Commandments", {{small|performed by T-Pain, [[Snoop Dogg]] and [[Mack Maine]]}} | composer = {{ubl|T-Pain|Tha Bizness|[[Young Fyre]] and Bishop Jones (additional music)}} | country = United States | language = English | network = [[Adult Swim]] | executive_producer = {{ubl|T-Pain|Carl Jones|Nick Weidenfeld|Ollie Green (co-executive producer)}} | producer = {{ubl|Georgette Perna|Monica Jones and Dave Newberg (associate producers)}} | editor = [[Dave Hughes (producer)|Dave Hughes]]
Nicholas Veith | company = {{ubl|[[Titmouse, Inc.]]|[[Nappy Boy Entertainment]]|[[Williams Street]]}} | distributor = [[Warner Bros. Television Distribution]] | runtime = {{ubl|44 minutes|49 minutes (uncut version)}} | picture_format = [[16:9]] [[HDTV]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2010|3|7}} }} '''''Freaknik: The Musical''''' is an [[United States|American]] [[Musical theatre|musical]] [[television special]] produced by [[T-Pain]]. It features the voice of T-Pain as the Ghost of Freaknik, as well as the voices of entertainers such as [[Lil Wayne]], [[Young Cash]], [[Snoop Dogg]], [[Sophia Fresh]], and [[Rick Ross]], and [[comedian]]s such as [[Andy Samberg]] and [[Charlie Murphy]] who provide additional voices. It was scheduled to air on [[Cartoon Network]]'s late night programming block [[Adult Swim]] sometime in 2009, but after several push-backs, it premiered on March 7, 2010. The musical is based on the actual music festival [[Freaknik|of the same name]] that used to take place in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. A [[#Soundtrack|soundtrack]] was released by [[Jive Records|Jive]] and [[Nappy Boy Entertainment|Nappy Boy]] on April 20, 2010. The 50-minute uncut version of ''Freaknik: The Musical'' has been released on [[DVD]] and other forms of home media. == Plot == The movie starts at a party that a group of young adults ([[Christopher "Kid" Reid]] and [[Affion Crockett]]) claims is the best [[House Party (film)|party]] they have ever attended. An elderly man ([[Lil Jon]]) joins the party and explains the history of [[Freaknik]]. He tells them that Freaknik threw the biggest party of all time, until it was broken up by the police in 1998; he claims the police "killed" Freaknik. Kid n' Play tried to convince that Freaknik is an urban legend like [[Candyman (film)|Candyman]], but as Play looks in the mirror, they were eaten by a swarm of wasps. The group is then led by the old man in [[summoning]] Freaknik, who appears as the Ghost of Freaknik Past ([[T-Pain]]). The scene changes to a radio announcer named Mr. Thanksgiving ([[DJ Drama]]), who is interviewing Freaknik. Mr. Thanksgiving and Freaknik explain that a rapping contest will be held, the victory of which will get "a lifetime supply of [[money]], [[clothes]], and [[Prostitution|hoes]]". The scene changes once more to the bedroom of Virgil ([[Young Cash]]), Big Uzi ([[Rick Ross]]), and Light Skin ([[CeeLo Green]]), collectively known as the Sweet Tea Mobsters, a group of young adult rappers from Sweet Tea, Florida, who hope to achieve fame. The group decides to drive to Atlanta to participate in the aforementioned contest, along with their [[Cannabis (drug)|weed]]-smoking (and supplying) friend Doela Man ([[DJ Pooh]]). During their journey, Light Skin tells of a secret society of African Americans called the [[Sigma Pi Phi|Boule]], fraternity parlance for "a council of noblemen", that seeks to guide the course of black culture. The members of this organization are parodies of [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[Al Sharpton]] ([[Charlie Murphy]]), [[Bill Cosby]] ([[Kel Mitchell]]), [[Russell Simmons]] ([[Affion Crockett]]), [[O. J. Simpson]], and [[Jesse Jackson]]. They wear medallions inscribed "10%", an allusion to the [[W. E. B. Du Bois]] essay [[The Talented Tenth]], which says that a class of exceptional members of the black race will rise to lead it. The Sweet Tea Mobsters make a number of pit stops, including a detour at a college fraternity party where they meet two alcoholic fraternity members ([[Bill Hader]] and [[Andy Samberg]]). While Virgil is fueling the gas tank, A car, inhabited by four sexy-looking women ([[Sophia Fresh]]) named Leacosia ([[Sophia Fresh|Crystal]]), Toprameneesha ([[Sophia Fresh|Skye]]), Obamaniqua ([[Sophia Fresh|Cole Rose]]), and Suzie ([[Sophia Fresh|Crystal]]), arrives. He tried to refuse, but the girls beg in song, besides Leacosia giving Virgil a kiss in the form of a gun. He accepts. Meanwhile, Freaknik meets Rev. Sharpton, who tried to force him to work for the Boule. The plan fails as Freaknik says that he will "never, ever turn his back on his own people", so he escorts Sharpton out via trapdoor. At the party, the group meets the Fruit Bowl Boys ([[Kel Mitchell]], [[Affion Crockett]], and [[Denzel Whitaker]]), who later become the group’s biggest competition and are from the mostly white suburbs of Sweet Tea, Florida (although they resemble the Sweet Tea Mobsters). On their long, winding road trip, the Sweet Tea Mob gets lost in New Orleans and are confronted by a gangster ([[Snoop Dogg]]) who makes them visit his boss, Trap Jesus ([[Lil Wayne]]). Upon meeting Trap Jesus, the group loses hope, thinking it is the end, but instead he inspires them to compete and gives them one of his many [[Lamborghini]]s to use to get to Atlanta. However, they crash the Lamborghini when Big Uzi becomes enraged after hearing the Fruit Bowl Boys talking about his jail experience. The group gives up except Virgil, who believes that winning the contest is their destiny. The rest of the group still doesn't believe him until they are given a ride in an airplane by the "Flying [[Malcolm X|Malcolms]]." Meanwhile, the Freaknik character is elected the "ghost mayor of Atlanta" and dubs the city "Freaknation." Soon after, President [[Barack Obama]] hands the presidency over to the ghost of Freaknik, a move that greatly angers Oprah, which wants to see Freaknik destroyed. She devises a plan to send a giant robotic monster called the "Perminator" (a robotic version of Al Sharpton, rebuilt from Sharpton's corpse after he got hit by lightning while blowing out his hair) to Atlanta to destroy Freaknik. Meanwhile, at the party, the Fruit Bowl Boys begin singing "Shank Ya in the Shower." The Sweet Tea Mobsters arrive at Atlanta at the same time as the Perminator begins its attack; it kills the Fruit Bowl Boys almost immediately. He seems to have Freaknik down for the count, but mass love from the crowd empowers Freaknik as the Mob performs, giving him the ability to grow to a monstrous size. Using the love of his fans, Freaknik is able to destroy the Perminator. After the fight, Freaknik declares the Sweet Tea Mobsters the winners of the contest, but Virgil refuses the prize and tears the check in half. He tells Freaknik that he doesn't need it as long as Freaknik comes back every year, but before he can finish speaking, a golden lion statue-shaped ship comes right in, inhabited by the members of the Boule. But as Freaknik is about to disqualify them, a dog-shaped spacecraft called the "[[Mothership Connection]]" arrives, killing the Boule and their ship (Note: This scene can only be seen on the uncut version of the special). It is inhabited by three brightly colored aliens who are actually [[George Clinton (musician)|George Clinton]], [[Bootsy Collins]], and Gene "King Poo Poo Man" Anderson. They say they have come to take Freaknik because "there are other galaxies that need his powers of positivity", saying that maybe someday he will return and they can "funk it up" once again. Freaknik gives Virgil his gold chain and says that Atlanta will always be his home. Suzie approaches Freaknik, telling him her baby (which looks like Freaknik) needs a father. Freaknik then rushes on board the ship with Clinton, Collins, and Anderson. Mr. Thanksgiving, the radio DJ from the beginning of the show, then speaks, saying how crazy that was and they'll see us next time; Freaknik is seen dancing on the Mothership as it leaves Earth. And after the end credits, we see Sweet Tea taping the check back together. == Voice cast == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[T-Pain]] as The Ghost of Freaknik Past * [[Rick Ross]] as Big Uzi Theodore * [[CeeLo Green]] as Light Skin Juliens * [[DJ Pooh]] as Doela Man * [[Young Cash]] as Virgil Gibson * [[Lil Jon]] as the foreboding old dude * [[DJ Drama]] as Mr. Thanksgiving * [[Kelis]] as [[Tyra Banks]] * [[Charlie Murphy]] as [[Al Sharpton]] * [[Andy Samberg]] as Chad * [[Bill Hader]] as Tad * [[Affion Crockett]] as [[Russell Simmons]], Fruit Bowl Boys member, [[Christopher "Play" Martin]], Riff, Flying Malcolm #1, various * [[Kel Mitchell]] as Fruit Bowl Boys frontman, [[Bill Cosby]], various * [[Big Boi]] as The Preacher * [[Snoop Dogg]] as gang member #1 * [[Mack Maine]] as gang member #2 * [[Lil Wayne]] as Trap Jesus * [[Sophia Fresh]] as Leacosia, Toprameneesha, Obamaniqua, Suzie * [[George Clinton (musician)|George Clinton]] as an alien version of himself * [[Bootsy Collins]] as an alien version of himself * Gene "King Poo Poo Man" Anderson as an alien version of himself * [[Corey Burton]] as The Balladeer, newscaster * [[Christopher "Kid" Reid]] as himself * Maronzio Vance as [[Jesse Jackson]] * Marlin Hill as [[Barack Obama]] * Carl Jones as a landlord and a partygoer * Liz Benoit as [[Oprah Winfrey]] * [[Denzel Whitaker]] as a member of the Fruit Bowl Boys * Georgette Perna as secretary, girl * Reggie Boyland as a partygoer {{end div col}} Additional voices are provided by: [[Gerald "Slink" Johnson]], Heather Lawless, Jason Van Veen, and Jason Walden. ==Production== ''Freaknik: The Musical'' originally evolved from a failed [[Television pilot|pilot]] entitled ''That Crook'd 'Sipp'' which was created by Mike Weiss, Jacob Escobedo, and [[Nick Weidenfeld]]. The pilot premiered on television on May 13, 2007.{{cite news|title=David Banner Debuts New Cartoon|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/latest-headlines/2007/05/david-banner-debuts-new-cartoon/|accessdate=28 April 2012|newspaper=[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]|date=May 14, 2007}}{{cite news|last=Mariel Concepcion|title=David Banner Premieres 'Crook'd' Cartoon|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1323683/david-banner-premieres-crookd-cartoon|accessdate=28 April 2012|newspaper=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=May 11, 2007}} Originally, the pilot was to receive six additional episodes scheduled to air sometime after 2007, but the episodes never surfaced and the show's status remained up in the air until mid-2009 when the series was scrapped for good in order to create this special.{{cite news|last=Chris J. Genius|title=T.I. To Release Cartoon Series|url=http://live.drjays.com/index.php/2010/08/21/t-i-to-release-cartoon-series/|accessdate=28 April 2012|newspaper=DrJaysLive|date=August 21, 2010}}{{cite news|title=Cartoon Creator Carl Jones On "Freaknik: The Musical" and Season 3 of "The Boondocks"|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2010/04/cartoon-creator-carl-jones-on-freaknik-the-musical-and-season-3-of-the-boondocks|accessdate=28 April 2012|newspaper=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|date=May 3, 2010}} Characters including Big Uzi, Suzy and Virgil all appeared in ''That Crook'd Sipp''. ==Reception== In its original American broadcast on March 7, 2010, ''Freaknik: The Musical'' was watched by 797,000 viewers 18-34, making it the second most watched Adult Swim program of that night, behind a rerun of ''[[Family Guy]]''.[http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2010/03/09/ratings-notes-for-tnt-tbs-adult-swim-trutv-and-cartoon-network/44408 Ratings Notes for TNT, TBS, Adult Swim, truTV and Cartoon Network] [[IGN]] gave this episode a 6.1 out of 10, which is considered "Passable", and received comments both positive and negative.[http://tv.ign.com/articles/107/1075123p1.html "Freaknik: The Musical" Review - TV Review at IGN] ==Home release == On March 8, 2010, the animated special was released for purchase on the [[iTunes Store]].[https://itunes.apple.com/us/tv-season/freaknik-the-musical/id355569070 ''Freaknik: The Musical''] at iTunes. The uncut 49-minute-long version of ''Freaknik: The Musical'' was released on one-disc [[DVD]] set in the United States on October 26, 2010,{{cite web|title=Freaknik: The Musical|url=https://www.amazon.com/Freaknik-Musical-T-Pain/dp/B003WOW5JU|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=22 May 2011}}{{cite web|title=DVD: Freaknik: The Musical|url=http://www.adultswimshop.com/cat/Freaknik/DVD-Freaknik-The-Musical.html|publisher=[[Adult Swim]]|accessdate=22 May 2011}} from [[Warner Home Video]] and included the soundtrack. === Soundtrack === It was announced by T-Pain that a soundtrack would be released through [[Jive Records]], [[Konvict Muzik]] and [[Nappy Boy Entertainment|Nappy Boy]] on April 20, 2010. The track "Ghetto Commandments", the credits outro song, was released on [[iTunes]] as a single on March 23 and it features rappers Snoop Dogg & Mack Maine who also play in the movie; it was released the same day as the release of T-Pain's promo single for his album "rEVOLVEr" "Reverse Cowgirl". The Rick Ross song "Grab Yo Beltloop" didn't make the final cut for the album. {{Tracklist | extra_column = Producer(s) | title1 = Freaknik Is Back | note1 = [[T-Pain]] a.k.a. '''Ghost of Freaknik''' | extra1 = Tha Bizness | length1 = 2:26 | title2 = Save You | note2 = [[T-Pain]] a.k.a. '''Ghost of Freaknik''' featuring [[One Chance (group)|One Chance]]'s Jon A. Gordon, Michael A. Gordon | extra2 = Tha Bizness | length2 = 3:42 | title3 = Ghetto Commandments | note3 = [[T-Pain]] a.k.a. '''Ghost of Freaknik''' featuring [[Snoop Dogg]] & [[Mack Maine]] | extra3 = Tha Bizness | length3 = 4:47 | title4 = We The Mob | note4 = [[T-Pain]] a.k.a. '''Ghost of Freaknik''' featuring Young Cash a.k.a. '''Virgil''' | extra4 = Ky Miller | length4 = 3:02 | title5 = Beat Build | note5 = [[T-Pain]] a.k.a. '''Ghost of Freaknik''' featuring Young Cash a.k.a. '''Virgil''' & [[Rick Ross (rapper)|Rick Ross]] a.k.a. '''Big Uzi''' | extra5 =Tha Bizness | length5 = 3:31 }} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == *{{official website|http://www.adultswim.com/presents/freaknik/}} *{{IMDb title|1535989|Freaknik: The Musical}} {{Adult Swim pilots and specials}} {{Williams Street}} {{T-Pain}} [[Category:Adult Swim pilots and specials]] [[Category:2010 television specials]] [[Category:Animated television specials]] [[Category:Atlanta in fiction]] [[Category:Musical television specials]] [[Category:Ghosts in television]] [[Category:African-American television]] [[Category:Hip hop television]] [[Category:2010s American television specials]]

revision.comment: Rock reliefs are a prominent aspect of [[Hittite art]].
revision.text:
{{Coord|display=title|37|45|13.4|N|34|39|25.4|E|type:landmark_region:TR-51}} {{Location map | Turkey | width = 300 | relief = 1 | lat_deg = 37 | lat_min = 45 | lat_sec = 13.4 | lat_dir = n | lon_deg = 34 | lon_min = 39 | lon_sec = 25.4 | lon_dir = e }} [[File:Gökbez1.jpg|thumb|Gökbez relief]] The [[Hittite empire|Hittite]] '''Gökbez relief''' is a [[rock relief]] at Gökbez and dates from the time of the [[Syro-Hittite states|Neo-Hittite states]]. Rock reliefs are a prominent aspect of [[Hittite art]].
== Location == The relief is in a courtyard in [[Gökbez, Bor|Gökbez]], [[Bor, Niğde|Bor]] district, [[Niğde Province]], [[Turkey]], about 12 km southeast of [[Kemerhisar]] and 22 km south of the provincial capital of [[Niğde]]. Kemerhisar is the site of the ancient city of [[Tyana]] and was centre of the minor [[Luwian]] state of [[Tuwanuwa]]. The ancient route from Tyana, through [[Faustinopolis|Halala]] to the [[Cilician Gates]], which were probably already in use in Hittite times.<ref>Dietrich Berges, Johannes Nollé: ''Tyana - Archäologisch-historische Untersuchungen zum südwestlichen Kappadokien''. Rudolf Habelt, Bonn 2000 {{ISBN|3-7749-2959-9}} p. 20</ref> The relief lies beside the old path.
== Description == The relief lies broken away and on its side in a courtyard in the village, leaning on the exterior wall of a house. The stone block measures 3.0 metres wide and 2.4 m high, the relief is 2.0 m x 2.0 m. The badly weathered image shows the god [[Tarhunna|Tarhunzas]] facing left. He holds a [[double axe]] in his right hand and a thunderbolt in his left. The god has a beard and long hair which falls to his shoulders. He is dressed in a knee-length robe with a broad belt. A vine grows up between his legs and grape clusters hang down beside him to the left. To the right of the figure is a double arch with a horizontal line running across it two thirds of the way up. [[Dietrich Berges]] and [[Johannes Nollé]] suggest that it probably originally contained (or was intended to contain) an inscription. Eringhaus thought it was a [[Phrygia]]n double idol, like that described by Dietrich Brendt at [[Yazılıkaya, Eskişehir|Midas Kenti]].<ref>Dietrich Berndt. "Midasstadt: Kleine und kleinste Felsmonumente. Überlegungen zu einer frühen Besiedlung." in Elmar Schwertheim, Engelbert Winter (Ed.): ''Neue Funde und Forschungen in Phrygien.'' Asia Minor Studien 61, 2006 pp. 1–32.</ref> The posture and costume of the figure show strong similarities to the [[Niğde Stele]] (on display in the [[Niğde Archaeological Museum]]), which also depicts Tarhunzas. For this reason, the relief is dated to the late 8th or early 7th century BC.
== References == <references />
== Bibliography== * Erol Faydalı. "Gökbez Kaya Kabartması." ''Anadolu'' 18, 1974, pp. 135–136 ([http://dergiler.ankara.edu.tr/dergiler/14/708/8934.pdf PDF]). * [[Dietrich Berges]], [[Johannes Nollé]]. ''Tyana - Archäologisch-historische Untersuchungen zum südwestlichen Kappadokien''. Rudolf Habelt, Bonn 2000 {{ISBN|3-7749-2959-9}} pp. 103–104. * [[Horst Ehringhaus]]. ''Das Ende, das ein Anfang war - Felsreliefs und Felsinschriften der luwischen Staaten Kleinasiens vom 12. bis 8./7. Jahrhundert v. Chr.'' Nünnerich-Asmus, Mainz 2014, {{ISBN|978-3-943904-67-3}} pp. 61–66.
== External links == * [http://www.hittitemonuments.com/gokbez/ Description on hittitemonuments.com]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gokbez relief}} [[Category:Hittite art]] [[Category:Hittite sites in Turkey]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in the Mediterranean Region, Turkey]] [[Category:Rock reliefs in Turkey]] [[Category:Niğde Province]]

[[Valuation (finance)|Valuation]] is considered as one of the most critical areas in [[finance]]; it plays a key role in many areas of [[finance]] such as buy/sell, [[solvency]], [[merger]] and [[Takeover|acquisition]].
==Rationale== There are numerous individual reasons or motivations for conducting an intellectual property valuation or economic [[Economic appraisal|appraisal]] analysis. A valuation is prepared, for example, for [[Financial transaction|transactions]], [[pricing]] and strategic purposes, [[financing]] [[securitization]] and [[collateralization]], [[tax]] planning and [[compliance (regulation)|compliance]], and litigation support.
==Factors driving the value of intellectual property==
Intellectual property derives its value from a wide range of significant parameters such as [[market share]], [[barriers to entry]], legal protection, IP’s profitability, [[Industry|industrial]] and [[economic]] factors, growth projections, remaining economic life, and new [[technologies]].
== Approaches== {{Unreferenced section|date=November 2008}} The valuation process necessitates gathering much more information as well as in-depth understanding of [[economy]], [[industry]], and specific business that directly affect the value of the [[intellectual property]]. Therefore, such information may be gathered from external and / or internal sources. Finally, the information is devoted to be turned into financial models to estimate the fundamental value of a particular type of intellectual property based on such adapted International Valuation Standards.
* [[Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice]] (USPAP) * [[International Valuation Standards Committee]] (IVSC) (50 Countries) * [[US Generally Accepted Accounting Principles]] (GAAP) * [[International Financial Reporting Standards]] (IFRS) * [[Financial Accounting Standards Board]] (FASB)
The valuation analysts use numerous approaches in order to reach a reasonable indication of a defined value for the subject intangible assets on a certain date which is referred to as the valuation date. The most common approaches to estimate the fundamental or fair value of the intellectual property are defined as the following:
1. '''Cost approach:''' The [[cost]] approach is based on the economic principle of [[substitution (economics)|substitution]]. This principle states that an [[investor]] will pay no more for an asset than the cost to obtain, by [[purchasing]] or constructing, a substitute asset of equal utility. There are several cost approach valuation methods, the most common being the historical cost, replacement cost, and replication cost.
2.''' Market approach:''' The [[Market (economics)|market]] approach is based on the [[economic]] principle of [[competition]] and [[Economic equilibrium|equilibrium]]. These principles conclude that, in a free and unrestricted [[Market (economics)|market]], [[supply and demand]] factors will drive the [[price]] of an asset at equilibrium point. Furthermore, it provides an indication of the value by comparing the price at which similar property has exchanged between willing buyers and sellers. Data on such similar transactions may be accessed in several public sources, including specialized royalty rate databases.{{cn|date=October 2014}}
3. '''Income approach:''' This approach estimates the fair value of intellectual property by discounting the future economic benefits of ownership at an appropriate discount rate.
4. '''Direct approach:''' The direct approach is based on the current value of shares of [[intellectual property]] in an Intellectual Property (IP) Share Market.<ref name="test">[http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/27084/title/Time-for-an-IP-Share-Market-/ 'Lyons-Weiler, J. 2009.', '''The Scientist'''], ''Time for an IP Share Market?''.</ref>
5. Using the pay-off method on top of the four above mentioned methods is a way to enhance the valuation and analysis of intellectual property <ref>[http://nopr.niscair.res.in/bitstream/123456789/12687/1/JIPR%2016%285%29%20377-384.pdf Collan, M. and Heikkilä, M., 2011, Enhancing Patent Valuation with the Pay-Off Method, Journal of Intellectual Property Rights, 16, 5, 377-384]</ref>
==See also== *[[Economics and patents]] * [[Patent valuation]] *[[International Valuation Standards Committee]] *[[Patent portfolio]] *[[Tax amortization benefit]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.wipo.int/sme/en/documents/valuationdocs/index.htm List of intellectual property valuation articles compiled by the World Intellectual Property Organisation] * [http://nopr.niscair.res.in/handle/123456789/12687 Patent valuation with the pay-off method, downloadable article]
[[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Valuation (finance)]]

{{Infobox film | name = João da Mata | image = | caption = | director = Amilar Alves | producer = Amilar Alves, Francisco Castelli, Victorino de Oliveira Prata, José Ziggiati | writer = Amilar Alves, Felipe Ricci | starring = Angelo Fortes | cinematography = Thomaz de Tullio | editing = Amilar Alves and Felipe Ricci | distributor = Phoenix Filmes | released = {{Film date|1923|10|09|df=y}} | runtime = | country = [[Brazil]] | language = Silent | budget = }} '''''João da Mata''''' is a [[1923 in film|1923]] [[Brazil]]ian silent political [[drama film]] directed by [[Amilar Alves]].
The film premiered in [[Rio de Janeiro]] on October 9, 1923
==Plot== The film questions the theme of land and Agrarian Reform in Brazil, and depicts the landowners known as "coronéis" in Portuguese as brutal and vindictive men. A lot of money, equipment and resources were employed for the film as it was considered an important topic at the time. Much of the film however has been destroyed and only fragments remain.
==Cast== *Amilar Alves *Nhá Ana *Juracy Aymoré *Eugênio Castelli *Moacir dos Santos *Angelo Fortes as João da Mata *Trajano Guimarães *Luiz Laloni *Arnaldo Pinheiro *Plínio Porto *José Rodrigues *José Ziggiati
==External links== * {{imdb title|id=0335216|title=João da Mata}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Joao Da Mata}} [[Category:1920s drama films]] [[Category:1923 films]] [[Category:Brazilian black-and-white films]] [[Category:Brazilian films]] [[Category:Brazilian silent films]] [[Category:Political films]]

'''Keshia Thomas''' is an [[African-American]] woman known for a 1996 event where she was photographed protecting a man believed to have been a [[Ku Klux Klan]] supporter.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kurylo|first=Anastacia|title=Inter/Cultural Communication: Representation and Construction of Culture|year=2012|publisher=SAGE Publications, Inc|isbn=1412986931|page=334|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=00xP0mZjiowC&pg=PA334&dq=%22keshia+thomas%22+kkk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=NNJwUpWnCcWisASW8YHYBg&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22keshia%20thomas%22%20kkk&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=MITCHELL |first1=MITCH |title=She risked her life saving a man at a KKK rally at 18. Now she helps Harvey victims |url=https://www.star-telegram.com/news/state/texas/article173180326.html |publisher=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]] |date=September 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Wynne |first1=Catherine |title=The teenager who saved a man with an SS tattoo |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-24653643 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=October 29, 2013}}</ref> The resulting photograph, which was taken by Mark Brunner, has been considered to be [[iconic]] in nature and was named one of [[Life (magazine)|''Life'' magazine's]] "Pictures of the Year" for 1996.<ref>{{cite book|title=Life Album 1996: Pictures of the Year|year=1999|publisher=Time-Life Books Editors|isbn=1883013119|page=79|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_tZS3WSoZQMC&q=%22Keshia+Thomas%22&dq=%22Keshia+Thomas%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_MpwUsm1M9TJsAS3voBA&ved=0CGMQ6AEwCA}}</ref>
==Rally== In June 1996 a branch of the Ku Klux Klan announced plans to hold a rally in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Mich. woman aids man being beaten|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/doc/290785877.html?FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:FT&type=current&date=Jun%2025,%201996&author=AP&pub=Boston%20Globe%20(pre-1997%20Fulltext)&edition=&startpage=&desc=Mich.%20woman%20aids%20man%20being%20beaten|accessdate=October 30, 2013|newspaper=Boston Globe|date=June 25, 1996}}</ref> Several people in the Ann Arbor area planned to hold a protest against the Ku Klux Klan's presence on the day of the rally. Thomas was one of several people that attended and protested from an area that had been fenced and set aside for the protesters.<ref name="TA">{{cite news|last=Paine|first=Chris|title=Why black teenager Keshia Thomas saved a white supremacist|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/why-black-teenager-keshia-thomas-saved-a-white-supremacist/story-e6frg6n6-1226749697993|accessdate=October 30, 2013|newspaper=The Australian}}</ref>
The protest proceeded until one protester announced over a megaphone that there was "a Klansman in the crowd".<ref name="TA"/> The unnamed man was a middle-aged white male wearing a T-shirt depicting the [[Confederate flag]] and an "SS tattoo".<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|last=Wynne|first=Catherine|title=The teenager who saved a man with an SS tattoo|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-24653643|accessdate=October 30, 2013|newspaper=BBC|date=October 28, 2013}}</ref> The man began to run but was knocked down, kicked, and beaten with [[placards]].<ref name="BBC"/>
Thomas, who was at that time 18 years old, shielded the man from the crowd and shouted for the attackers to stop and is credited as saying that you "can't beat goodness into a person".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gillette|first1=Ethel|title=As Thanksgiving Day approaches, there is much to be thankful about |newspaper=The Tampa Tribune |date=November 19, 2000}}</ref> Shortly after that point the police arrived on the scene.<ref name="HDE">{{cite news|title=Teen Who Saved Man At Klan Rally Wanted to Stop Mob Attack|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fk9BAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4qgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4988,2510165&dq=keshia-thomas&hl=en|accessdate=October 30, 2013|newspaper=Harlan Daily Enterprise|date=June 25, 1996}}</ref>
A news report stated that seven anti-Klansmen protesters were arrested at the event and a large group of protesters were [[tear gas]]sed after they attempted to enter the police station where fifteen Klansmen were being kept for their safety.<ref name="HDE"/> The police later reported that the man was not a Klan member.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guardian Angel|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20141729,00.html|accessdate=October 30, 2013|newspaper=People magazine|date=July 8, 1996}}</ref>
==Aftermath== After the rally Thomas was praised for her actions by Senator [[Ernest Hollings]] and a reporter for ''The Day'' commented that while the man was "wrong for the views he sanctioned", the protesters were also in the wrong "in their violence against him".<ref>{{cite news|title=Alone in the Mob|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vw1HAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JvgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4178,1693389&dq=keshia-thomas&hl=en|accessdate=October 30, 2013|newspaper=The Day|date=July 11, 1996}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hollings|first1=Ernest F.|title=KESHIA THOMAS: LEADING BY EXAMPLE|url=http://congressional.proquest.com/congressional/docview/t17.d18.c4b088c70e001e9a?accountid=10559|accessdate=February 21, 2016|issue=Vol. 142 No. 97 Pg. S7204|publisher=Congressional Record Daily Edition (subscription required)|date=June 27, 1996}}</ref>
Thomas expressed that she had protected the man due to her own religious convictions and because she "knew what it was like to be hurt ... The many times that that happened, I wish someone would have stood up for me." A few months after the June event, Thomas was thanked by the son of the unnamed man she rescued.<ref name="BBC"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thomas, Keshia}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Michigan]] [[Category:Black-and-white photographs]] [[Category:People notable for being the subject of a specific photograph]] [[Category:African-American women]] [[Category:1996 works]] [[Category:1996 in art]] [[Category:1990s photographs]]

{{Orphan|date=December 2016}} This is a list of fiction works that have been made into [[feature films]]. The title of the work and the year it was published are both followed by the work's author, the title of the film, and the year of the film. If a film has an alternate title based on geographical distribution, the title listed will be that of the widest distribution area. {{inc-lit}} {{inc-film}} {{Compact ToC|num=yes |center=yes|Sec1=Short stories and novellas|seealso=yes|notes=yes}} == Books == === D === {| class="wikitable" |- ! width="450"|Fiction work(s) !! width="450"|Film adaptation(s) |- | ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'' (2003), [[Dan Brown]] | ''[[The Da Vinci Code (film)|The Da Vinci Code]]'' (2006) |- | ''Dad'' (1981), [[William Wharton (author)|William Wharton]] | ''[[Dad (film)|Dad]]'' (1989) |- | ''[[Damage (Hart novel)|Damage]]'' (1991), [[Josephine Hart]] | ''[[Damage (1992 film)|Damage]]'' (1992) |- | ''[[Damnation Alley]]'' (1967), [[Roger Zelazny]] | ''[[Damnation Alley (film)|Damnation Alley]]'' (1977) |- | ''[[The Damned Utd]]'' (2006), [[David Peace]] | ''[[The Damned United]]'' (2009) |- | ''[[The Dancer Upstairs]]'' (1995), [[Nicholas Shakespeare]] | ''[[The Dancer Upstairs (film)|The Dancer Upstairs]]'' (2002) |- | ''Dances with Wolves'' (1986), [[Michael Blake (author)|Michael Blake]] | ''[[Dances with Wolves]]'' (1990) |- | ''A Dandy in Aspic'' (1966), [[Derek Marlowe]] | ''A Dandy in Aspic'' (1968) |- | ''The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys'' (2001), [[Chris Fuhrman]] | ''[[The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys]]'' (2002) |- | ''[[Daniel Deronda]]'' (1876), [[George Eliot]] | ''[[Daniel Deronda#1921 film|Daniel Deronda]]'' (1921)

* ''Ashes of Old Wishes and Other Darby O'Gill Tales'' (1926), Herminie Templeton Kavanagh | ''[[Darby O'Gill and the Little People]]'' (1959) |- | ''[[The Dark Fields]]'' (2001), [[Alan Glynn]] | ''[[Limitless (film)|Limitless]]'' (2011) |- | ''[[The Dark Is Rising Sequence]]'' (1965–1977) (series), [[Susan Cooper]] | ''[[The Seeker: The Dark is Rising]]'' (2007) |- | ''The Dark of the Sun'' (1965), [[Wilbur Smith]] | ''[[Dark of the Sun]]'' (1968) |- | ''[[Dark Passage]]'' (1946), [[David Goodis]] | ''[[Dark Passage (film)|Dark Passage]]'' (1947) |- | ''[[David Copperfield (novel)|David Copperfield]]'' (1849-1850) (serial) (1850) (novel), [[Charles Dickens]] | ''[[David Copperfield (1911 film)|David Copperfield]]'' (1911)
''[[David Copperfield (1913 film)|David Copperfield]]'' (1913)
''[[David Copperfield (1922 film)|David Copperfield]]'' (1922)
''[[David Copperfield (1935 film)|David Copperfield]]'' (1935)
